intro: Veronica virginica var. hirsuta, commonly known as hairy blueweed, is a perennial herb native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Plantaginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as wetlands and streambanks. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. The flowers are clustered in dense spikes, adding to its ornamental value in native gardens.
